newsitem.title: SPAIN: Waigel reported saying EU finances need overhaul.
newsitem.headline: Waigel reported saying EU finances need overhaul.

text.p: European Union financing needs overhauling, according to comments by German Finance Minister Theo Waigel reported in Spain's El Pais newspaper on Monday.
The newspaper reported Waigel suggested Germany was paying too much into EU coffers and that Spain was taking too much out.
El Pais said the comments were in a letter from Waigel to German Chancellor Helmut Kohl which was distributed to his cabinet.

"Our objective has to be braking the growth in expenditure in the community," Waigel said in the letter, which El Pais said was marked "personal, confidential and not destined for publication." The newspaper did not say how it got hold of the letter.
In Bonn, a German government source who asked not to be identified confirmed the letter from Waigel to Kohl was genuine but said it was a routine informational briefing and not secret.

In the letter, Waigel pointed out the high burden of the EU budget on Germany, which paid a net 11.5 billion Ecus in 1995, while Spain received 7.5 billion Ecus. This has a negative impact on acceptance of the EU by the German public, the letter said, according to the German government source.
El Pais said Waigel's letter said Spain was taking "the lion's share" of the budget, referring to graphs showing funding and expenditure levels.
"We need a system to limit the excessive net transfers not only for budgetary reasons but also for reasons of political acceptance in Europe," El Pais cited the letter as saying.
